nodes.text: A galaxy was a massive, gravitationally bound assemblage of stars, an interstellar medium of gas and dust, and an unknown type of dark matter. Typical galaxies contained ten million to one trillion (107 to 1012) stars, all orbiting a common center of gravity. Galaxies could also contain a large number of star systems and star clusters as well as black holes and various types of nebulae.
The Intergalactic Void was the space between the galaxies.
